facts.text: Appellant was appointed by the Local Self-Government Department, Government of Rajasthan by order dated 27.11.1974 as Lady Doctor under Municipal Council, Ganganagar

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed by the Local Self- Government Department, Government of Rajasthan by order of appointment dated 27.11.1974, and posted as Lady Doctor under the Municipal Council, Ganganagar.

facts.text: Appointment was purely on temporary basis for six months or till candidate selected by Rajasthan Public Service Commission is available, whichever earlier

anchor.surface_text: There was a stipulation in the order of appointment that she was being posted purely on temporary basis for the period of six months or till the candidate selected by the Rajasthan Public Service Commission  hereinafter referred to as the Service Commission  is available, whichever is earlier.

facts.text: Appellant's working period continued to be extended

anchor.surface_text: The working period of the appellant companytinued to be extended.

facts.text: Appointment made under Section 308 of Rajasthan Municipalities Act, 1959 read with Rules 26 and 27 of Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963

anchor.surface_text: The appointment was made in exercise of powers companyferred under Section 308 of the Rajasthan Municipalities Act, 1959  in short the Act  read with Rules 26 and 27 of the Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963  in short the Rules .

facts.text: Appellant selected by Service Commission in October 1976 and August 1982 but did not join

anchor.surface_text: Though the appellant was selected by the Service Commission in October 1976 and August 1982 she did number join pursuant to such selection and companytinued on the basis of the orders of extension issued by the Local Self-Government Department of the Government.

facts.text: Appellant's services terminated on 1.10.1988 on ground that candidate selected by Service Commission was available

anchor.surface_text: On 1.10.1988 appellants services were terminated on the ground that the candidate selected by the Service Commission was available.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition number 3739 of 1988 before Rajasthan High Court challenging termination

anchor.surface_text: Challenging such dismissal, appellant filed a writ petition bearing number 3739 of 1988 before the Rajasthan High Court.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court passed interim order of stay on 12.10.1988 directing appellant not to be relieved

anchor.surface_text: Interim order of stay was passed on 12.10.1988 by the High Court with the direction that the appellant was number to be relieved from her post if she was number already relieved.

facts.text: Interim order made absolute by Rajasthan High Court on 21.3.1989

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the interim order was made absolute by order dated 21.3.1989.

facts.text: Single Judge of Rajasthan High Court by judgment dated 5.3.1993 held termination illegal due to 14 years service, directed to adjudge suitability and regularize

anchor.surface_text: By judgment dated 5.3.1993, learned Single Judge held that termination of appellants services was illegal since order was passed ignoring of the fact that she had put in 14 years of service. The authorities were directed to adjudge her suitability within a period of one month and regularize her services with all benefits available to a substantively appointed member of the service.

facts.text: State of Rajasthan filed appeal to Division Bench of Rajasthan High Court

anchor.surface_text: The State of Rajasthan filed appeal before the Division Bench of the Rajasthan High Court.

facts.text: Division Bench by judgment dated 11.4.1997 held appellant continued as temporary employee under Rule 27, no right to hold post

anchor.surface_text: But by the impugned judgment dated 11.4.1997, it was held by the Division Bench that the appellant companytinued merely as a temporary employee on the basis of appointment made under Rule 27 as she had number been selected by the Service Commission in accordance with the Rules. She had numberright to hold the post.

facts.text: Appellant had put in 14 years service by time of termination order

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant submitted that by number she had put in 28 years of service 14 years by the time the order of termination was passed

facts.text: Appellant continued 14 more years on basis of interim directions by High Court and Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: 14 years by the time the order of termination was passed and 14 years on the basis of interim directions given by the High Court and this Court.

facts.text: Appellant applied for voluntary retirement nearly two years back, no final decision taken

anchor.surface_text: She has applied for voluntary retirement nearly two years back and numberfinal decision has been taken.

facts.text: Appellant given privileges under Gratuity and Pension Fund Benefit Schemes under Rajasthan Municipal Services Pension Rules, 1989

anchor.surface_text: Residually it was submitted that the appellant has been given the privileges available under the Gratuity and Pension Fund Benefit Schemes available under Rajasthan Municipal Services  Pension  Rules, 1989  in short Pension Rules .

issues.text: whether the appellants termination from service is in order

anchor.surface_text: The only point involved in this appeal is whether the appellants termination from service is in order. Factual scenario which is almost undisputed is as follows-

issues.text: Whether the temporary appointment under Rules 26 and 27 could be continued beyond one year without reference to the Commission for concurrence and whether long continuance regularizes the appointment

anchor.surface_text: As the initial order of appointment dated 27.11.1974 shows appellant was appointed in terms of Rules 26 and 27. It was clearly indicated that the appointment was made on a temporary basis with further condition

issues.text: Whether the appellant has a right to regularization of services despite not being selected by the Service Commission due to long service

anchor.surface_text: Challenging such dismissal, appellant filed a writ petition bearing number 3739 of 1988 before the Rajasthan High Court. ... The Division Bench overlooked the salient features and held that the temporary appointment originally made continued to hold field.

issues.text: Whether the principles of legitimate expectation are applicable to claim continuance or regularization

anchor.surface_text: What remains to be considered is the plea of legitimate expectation. The principle of legitimate expectation is still at a stage of evolution as pointed out in De Smith Administrative Law

issues.text: Whether presumption of Service Commission's concurrence can be drawn from grant of extensions

anchor.surface_text: Another plea of the appellant needs to be noted. With reference to the extension granted it was contended that a presumption of the Service Commissions concurrence can be drawn, when extensions were granted from time to time. This plea is without any substance.

The authorities were directed to adjudge her suitability within a period of one month and regularize her services with all benefits available to a substantively appointed member of the service.

She has applied for voluntary retirement nearly two years back and no final decision has been taken. These benefits cannot be denied to her.

Appellant cannot take advantage of the fortuitous circumstance that she continued for 14 years.

arguments.claim: Appointment under Rule 27(1) cannot continue beyond one year without Commission concurrence; terminates on refusal

anchor.surface_text: As the initial order of appointment dated 27.11.1974 shows appellant was appointed in terms of Rules 26 and 27. It was clearly indicated that the appointment was made on a temporary basis with further condition that if candidate selected by the Service Commission is available, the employment was to come to end automatically. Sub-rule  2  of Rule 27 is of considerable importance.

arguments.claim: No presumption of Service Commission concurrence from grant of extensions; plea without substance

anchor.surface_text: Another plea of the appellant needs to be noted. With reference to the extension granted it was contended that a presumption of the Service Commissions concurrence can be drawn, when extensions were granted from time to time. This plea is without any substance.

arguments.claim: Precedents relied by petitioner in different factual backgrounds; no general rule for regularization from long ad-hoc service

anchor.surface_text: The decisions relied upon by the learned counsel for the appellant were rendered in different factual background. A decision is an authority for what it decides and not for what could be inferred from the conclusion.

arguments.claim: No legitimate expectation as no waiver of appointment conditions shown; mere continuance insufficient

anchor.surface_text: What remains to be considered is the plea of legitimate expectation. ... On the facts of the case delineated above, the principle of legitimate expectation has no application. It has not been shown as to how any act was done by the authorities which created an impression that the conditions attached in the original appointment order were waived.

arguments.claim: Division Bench judgment correct; termination in order; no interference needed

anchor.surface_text: The inevitable conclusion is that Division Bench judgment is on terra firma and needs no interference.

holdings.text: Appellant's termination from service is in order as she continued merely as a temporary employee under Rule 27 without selection by the Service Commission and had no right to hold the post

anchor.surface_text: As the initial order of appointment dated 27.11.1974 shows appellant was appointed in terms of Rules 26 and 27. It was clearly indicated that the appointment was made on a temporary basis with further condition that if candidate selected by the Service Commission is available, the employment was to come to end automatically.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointment explicitly temporary under Rules 26/27; terminates automatically on PSC candidate availability; no PSC selection despite opportunities; Division Bench correctly held no right to post

holdings.text: No appointment under Rule 27(1) can continue beyond one year without reference to the Commission for concurrence and terminates on refusal

anchor.surface_text: Sub-rule (2) of Rule 27 is of considerable importance. It specifically lays down no appointment made under sub-rule (1) shall be continued beyond a period of one year without referring to the Commission for their concurrence and shall be terminated immediately on their refusal to concur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Rule 27(2) text; nature of employment clearly spelt out; no automatic extension without reference

holdings.text: There is no scope for regularization unless the appointment was on regular basis through Service Commission selection

anchor.surface_text: The appointment to the post of Lady Doctor in the Municipal Council is required to be made by selection through the medium of the Service Commission. That undisputedly has not been done. There is no scope of regularization unless the appointment was on regular basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regular appointment mandates PSC selection; long continuance or ad-hoc nature does not confer regularization right; precedents distinguished as different facts

holdings.text: No presumption of Service Commission's concurrence can be drawn from grant of extensions; plea without substance

anchor.surface_text: Another plea of the appellant needs to be noted. With reference to the extension granted it was contended that a presumption of the Service Commissions concurrence can be drawn, when extensions were granted from time to time. This plea is without any substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 27(2) requires explicit reference after one year; extensions do not imply concurrence; currency lost after one year

holdings.text: Principle of legitimate expectation has no application on the facts

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of the case delineated above, the principle of legitimate expectation has no application. It has not been shown as to how any act was done by the authorities which created an impression that the conditions attached in the original appointment order were waived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No representation, reliance, or detriment shown; mere continuance does not create expectation or imply waiver; requires clear act by authorities; public interest in PSC selection overrides

holdings.text: Division Bench judgment is correct and needs no interference

anchor.surface_text: The inevitable conclusion is that Division Bench judgment is on terra firma and needs no interference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds Division Bench application of Rule 27; rejects Single Judge's reliance on long service; consistent with rules and precedents

justification_sets.label: Rule 27 Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963 support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
